content.description: Cool boulder sequence down low, thin and graceful, powerful and slightly overhung - all leads to some milder climbing with an interesting move up high
content.location: Now the farthest left on the wall, the only bolted line left of the final corner

content.description: Still chossy, sort of a dihedral with a bit of an arete on one side. Watch out for the small tree stump that nearly took out my manhood when a rock broke!
content.location: Almost to the left end of the wall, second climb from left, shares anchors with the climb to the left - in a dihedral sort of corner.

content.description: Follow the first two bolts from the line to the left, and then make a slightly unnerving traverse right to the third bolt (don't fall). Use pockets and edges to make it through the deceptive thinness to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts (first two shared with line to left), single-ring anchors.
content.location: Third-from-left. Shares first two bolts with line to the left.

content.description:
Step up on good feet to a disconcertingly thin and flexible flake just before the first bolt. Continue up through a bulge using underclings and sidepulls, with a few pockets thrown in to make it interesting.

Positive edges await after the crux with easier climbing to the chains.
content.location: Second-from-left. Another route splits right at the second bolt.

content.description: An undercut start using sidepulls and poor feet leads to more positive holds above, followed pockets near the top. Slopey jugs then lead to the anchors.
content.location: Left-most line at the wall.

content.description: Short with bouldery crux in the middle.
content.location: To the right of and shares anchor with Drop Anchor.

content.description: This is a great climb with unique movement.  The climbing builds in intensity with the crux being the point where the wall starts to decrease in steepness.  Fun pockets and crimps.
content.protection: 7 bolts, shares anchors with Bon Voyage
content.location: Line to the left of Cinnamon Bay.

content.description:
Enjoyable climbing in a corner with pockets and stemming. Big sidepulls and occasional crack features lead up the corner weakness with a slight bulge near the top. A few large pockets that you'll feel guilty about not using because there are too many other holds.

If you contrived to stay on the face only it'd probably be mid-5.10.
content.location:
The line immediately left of a corner, near the left side of the crag. After coming around a bulge and uphill slightly there are two short, bolted lines on the south face of the bulge and a corner immediately left of the bulge.

This line is the three bolts to the left of the corner.

content.description: A fairly mellow, yet balancy start leads to an almost-ledge and the second bolt. A committing move or two with tricky, somewhat poor feet leads to a mostly-out-of-sight, positive (yet smallish) hold and ok edges. Clip the third bolt, head up and traverse right to the anchors for the route to the right.
content.protection: 3 bolts, single-ring anchors (above the line to the right).
content.location: Seventh from the left, or the second line left of the corner. No anchors directly above the line; single ring anchors above the line to the right.

content.description: A nice line on great rock!  The crux comes at the traverse after clipping the 4th bolt.   Positive pockets and jugs to the finish.
content.location: 2 routes to the left of Margarita

content.description:
Burly start on undercut rock to awkward, narrow ledge, followed by a short dihedral to a larger ledge. From the ledge a tricky move or two with a two-finger pocket leads to liebacking and stemming with a bit of hand jamming thrown in.

Falling while clipping the 3rd bolt above the ledge (6th bolt overall) will guarantee a hard hit onto the ledge.
content.protection:
8 bolts, chain anchors (shared with a .12b to the right).

There is also an orphaned bolt to the left, just above the ledge.
content.location: Runs up the corner on the right of a close-to-vertical, smoother section near the mid-point of the wall.

content.description: The crux is the opening moves.  Use sharp but positive pockets and then head up and right to the flat shelf.  The foot holds in the beginning are really tiny.
content.location: The second route from the right.  Joins its neighbor at the 3rd bolt.

content.description: This route makes a decent warm up for some of the harder stuff.  I would not hike up here to project this route.  It does have some fun moves though.  The climbing starts off with the hardest moves and after the 2nd bolt it gradually gets easier.
content.location: This is the left most route before the hand line.

content.description: Continuous, back and forward on the face/arete.
content.location: 50 ft left of Easter Island. Scramble up to the base of a left facing arete.

content.description: The crux is at the start, so stick clipping the first or second bolt is a good idea.   Start on positive pockets with small and slippery feet.  Gain the flat shelf at the 3rd bolt and then sinker pockets to the finish.   The finish is a bit run, but easy, and may be a bit dirty if it has not been done in a while.  Could serve as a warm up for the area.
content.location: This is the right most line on the south facing wall where there approach trail meets the wall.   It joins Screaming Lobsters at the 3rd bolt.

content.description: A bit tricky to the first bolt followed by pockets and edges to the second bolt. A bit run out to the third using good holds but long reaches (don't blow the third clip). Less-than-totally-positive edges then lead up and to the chains.
content.location: Fifth from the left of the crag, or fourth right of the corner.

content.description: One of two routes at the crag that have rose moves! Start on pockets and bust straight into the crux boulder problem, stab to a two finger pocket, rose move to another two finger pocket, and make another stab move! After that it's fun pocket climbing to a red point crux up high!
content.location: This route can be found to the left of Blue Typhoon.

content.description: The start is not as bad as it appears as the undercling is quite good.   Continue up and trend right.  The crux comes at the 5th bolt.  On the onsight, the top appears to go right on to the finish of Drifting, but you can go straight up for an independent finish which is of similar difficulty but the holds are a bit harder to see.  This route could make for a nice warm up for some of the harder lines in this area once you have the beta sorted.
content.location: start just to the right of Razor Clam.  Starting directly below the first bolt, this one has an independent start from Razor Clam.

content.description: A tricky, mildly strenuous start with a pocket, slightly-less-positive-edges than you'd like gets you past the first bolt to the second. Pockets lead upward to larger edges, then a traverse right to the anchors above the line to the right.
content.protection: 4 bolts, chains anchors (use those above the line that is to the right).
content.location: Fourth route from the left, or, counting from the corner to the right of this line, the fifth line left of the corner.

content.description: Bouldery at the start, middle and end.
content.location: Starts just right of Lion Fish.

content.description: To climb High Tide, start on Dark Rum and climb through the steepest part of the black bulge. Where the bolt line splits, go left and climb just right of the arete to the chains. 11d/12a
content.protection: Bolts. Anchors had aluminum wire gates as of 4/3/2021.
content.location: Start off the ground beneath the ledge.

content.description:
Fire the first three bolts of Margarita, then traverse right on decent pockets for two bolts before heading straight up following small crimps and blocky holds to a set of anchors at the lip of the crag.

Really pretty rock, and very reasonable for the grade(if you have some endurance), with the hardest moves being the Margarita start.

Watch out for aging gear on this route.  The bolts are rusty, and a few draws look like they have been there a very long time.
content.location: Same start as Margarita.  At fourth bolt look for bolts moving right and then up to a set of anchors at top of wall.

content.description: Burly. Stick clip the second bolt.
content.location: Between D Ice and T Depression.

content.description: Up the thin seam that looks like it should be way easier than it is. Cruxy all the way.
content.location: The obvious seam 30ft left of Sea Cliff.

content.description: Burly start on pockets with a reachy move or two leads to small feet and sidepulls.
content.location:
A number of moderate-appearing lines are at the far left end of the wall. This line appears to  the right of a corner, and shares anchors with an .11d to the right (

Tuna Melt

: it isn't in the Ruckman guide).

content.description: Super technical face climb up the nice black wall. Start off the ground and go directly through the steepest part of the black bulge. Move right where the bolt line splits and finish up a thin face.
content.location: Starts 50ft left of Easter Island, just left and below Pina Colada.

content.description: Has the same hard start as Bamboo. Then some great climbing through pods.
content.location: Starts same as Bamboo then moves right.

content.description: A bouldery route, with excellent moves and bomber rock.   Starts on positive pockets and small feet.  Crux is exiting the undercling at the 3rd bolt.   This route stays dry when all the others are wet up here.
content.protection: 5 bolts, shuts.   Fixed draw on last bolt and anchors.
content.location: Upon reaching the Southfacing wall, head west along the cliff.  After climbing up the eroding hillside on a handline, this is the second route from the right.

content.description: Positive edges and pockets to a small roof with a tricky move or two to get over.
content.protection: 6 bolts, chain anchors. Anchors aren't visible from below.
content.location: A number of moderate-appearing lines are at the far left end of the wall. This line is the third line left of an obvious corner; the line is easily identified by the bolt count (six).

content.description:
This is one of the quintessential hard routes of American Fork - the one we have all stared at on the cover of the Ruckman guidebook. Nothing quite compares to the aesthetic beauty of the rock, and complexity of the movement required to put this thing down.

This route is in your face from the get-go. Start off with a hard boulder problem utilizing very small crimps. I've seen it done two ways; it's probably the same difficulty either way. Make big, powerful, dynamic moves in the dihedral until it's possible to move out left on very positive pockets. After a few hard traversing moves, a big deadpoint to a positive finger-jug leads to an ok rest. Catch your breath. A few more moves on small holds guard the final jug rail where the chains are easily clipped.
content.location: This is the first route you get to from the approach trail. Look for a shallow dihedral and cool blue streaks. It's located to the left of Screaming Lobsters.

content.description:
A boulder problem start with small feet and a grunty exit gives way to the finest techy, powerful 5.12 climbing American Fork has to offer. This thing is full value power endurance.

Get your fingers ready to crank off of small crimps and amazing two finger pockets. Expect delicate footwork and a high pump factor, given that there aren't many great rests. The crux is smack dab in the middle of the route where the prow is at its steepest. After that, 2 bolts of easy slab take you to the chains.
content.location: To the right of Seacliff (10d), left of Bon Voyage (12d)

content.description:
"Simple to figure out, difficult to execute." - American Fork Canyon Rock Climbing Guide

This route shares the first bolt of Margarita (5.12).  Head straight up at the first bolt using the available pockets.  The crux is found between the 3rd and 4th bolt. Bust some challenging sequential, pocketed moves.  A micro crux is found up higher before the route changes angles.  A short, but stout American Fork Classic!
content.location: This route is found just left of the steepest part of the wall, as you come up the trail.  To the left of Margarita.  This shares the first bolt.
